page.title: 04DENEHOLES, GRAYS
page.content: Within the four acres of Hangmans Wood seventy two deneholes have been counted. They are mostly together. The shafts are a little over a metre in diameter, and end in caves branching into chambers about seven metres long. The shafts are now gradually closing in with the soil all around and the debris from above. Many pits show a heap of sand at the base. Each pit is separate from its neighbour. Many suggestions have been made as to the purpose of deneholes. Were they goldmines? Of gold there was none, but flints were found in plenty, a fact supporting the theory that they were flint mines. Niches stained brown in the walls indicate a form of lighting was used.Evidence suggests they may have been used for grain storage, but their real purpose is yet to be seen.
